Line 23: Line 23:
Mohamed Bouazizi, who was known locally as ''Basboosa'',<ref name="gulfnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/opinions/editorials/tunisia-events-turning-point-in-arab-world-1.746884|title=Tunisia events turning point in Arab world|work=[[Gulf News]]|accessdate=2011-01-22}}</ref> was born in [[Sidi Bouzid]], [[Tunisia]], on March 29, 1984. His father, a construction worker in [[Libya]], died of a heart attack when Bouazizi was three, and his mother married Bouazizi's uncle some time later.<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/22/world/africa/22sidi.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2&src=twrhp|author=Fahim, Kareem|title=Slap to a Manâs Pride Set Off Tumult in Tunisia|work=[[New York Times]]|date=2011-01-21|page=2|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> Along with his six siblings,<ref name="independent1"/> Bouazizi was educated in a one-room country school in Sidi Salah, a village {{convert|12|mi|km}} from Sidi Bouzid.<ref name="guardian1">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/20/tunisian-fruit-seller-mohammed-bouazizi|title=Mohammed Bouazizi: the dutiful son whose death changed Tunisia's fate|author=Beaumont, Peter|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2011-01-20|accessdate=2011-01-23|location=London}}</ref> Although multiple media outlets reported that Bouazizi had a university degree,<ref name="independent1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/101313/20110114/the-story-of-mohamed-bouazizi-the-man-who-toppled-tunisia.htm#|title=The Story of Mohamed Bouazizi, the man who toppled Tunisia|publisher=[[International Business Times|IBTimes]]|date=2011-01-14|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kurdishaspect.com/doc011711DJ.html|title=What Can We Do for Freedom|author=Jaf, Dana|publisher=Kurdish Aspect|date=2011-01-17|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> his sister, Samia Bouazizi, stated that he had never graduated from high school,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/tunisia/man-at-the-centre-of-tunisia-unrest-recuperating-doctors-say-1.738967|title=Man at the centre of Tunisia unrest recuperating, doctors say|author=Toumi, Habib|work=[[Gulf News]]|date=2010-12-31|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> but that it was something he had wanted for both himself and his sisters.<ref name="guardian1"/> With his uncle in poor health and unable to work regularly,<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|author=Ryan, Yasmine|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/201111684242518839.html|title=The tragic life of a street vendor|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=2011-01-16|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> Bouazizi had worked various jobs since he was ten,<ref name="nytimes1"/> and in his late teens he quit school in order to work full-time.<ref name="aljazeera1"/>
Mohamed Bouazizi, who was known locally as ''Basboosa'',<ref name="gulfnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/opinions/editorials/tunisia-events-turning-point-in-arab-world-1.746884|title=Tunisia events turning point in Arab world|work=[[Gulf News]]|accessdate=2011-01-22}}</ref> was born in [[Sidi Bouzid]], [[Tunisia]], on March 29, 1984. His father, a construction worker in [[Libya]], died of a heart attack when Bouazizi was three, and his mother married Bouazizi's uncle some time later.<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/22/world/africa/22sidi.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2&src=twrhp|author=Fahim, Kareem|title=Slap to a Manâs Pride Set Off Tumult in Tunisia|work=[[New York Times]]|date=2011-01-21|page=2|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> Along with his six siblings,<ref name="independent1"/> Bouazizi was educated in a one-room country school in Sidi Salah, a village {{convert|12|mi|km}} from Sidi Bouzid.<ref name="guardian1">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/20/tunisian-fruit-seller-mohammed-bouazizi|title=Mohammed Bouazizi: the dutiful son whose death changed Tunisia's fate|author=Beaumont, Peter|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2011-01-20|accessdate=2011-01-23|location=London}}</ref> Although multiple media outlets reported that Bouazizi had a university degree,<ref name="independent1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/101313/20110114/the-story-of-mohamed-bouazizi-the-man-who-toppled-tunisia.htm#|title=The Story of Mohamed Bouazizi, the man who toppled Tunisia|publisher=[[International Business Times|IBTimes]]|date=2011-01-14|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kurdishaspect.com/doc011711DJ.html|title=What Can We Do for Freedom|author=Jaf, Dana|publisher=Kurdish Aspect|date=2011-01-17|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> his sister, Samia Bouazizi, stated that he had never graduated from high school,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/tunisia/man-at-the-centre-of-tunisia-unrest-recuperating-doctors-say-1.738967|title=Man at the centre of Tunisia unrest recuperating, doctors say|author=Toumi, Habib|work=[[Gulf News]]|date=2010-12-31|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> but that it was something he had wanted for both himself and his sisters.<ref name="guardian1"/> With his uncle in poor health and unable to work regularly,<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|author=Ryan, Yasmine|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/201111684242518839.html|title=The tragic life of a street vendor|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=2011-01-16|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> Bouazizi had worked various jobs since he was ten,<ref name="nytimes1"/> and in his late teens he quit school in order to work full-time.<ref name="aljazeera1"/>
â
Bouazizi lived in a modest stucco home, a 20-minute walk from the center of Sidi Bouzid,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0119/In-town-at-center-of-Tunisia-uprising-23-years-of-repressed-emotions-burst-forth|author=Chick, Kristen|title=Tunisian emotions burst forth|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref><ref name="reuters1">{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE70G18J20110119 |title=Peddler's martyrdom launched Tunisia's revolution|author=Noueihed, Lin|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> a rural town in Tunisia burdened by corruption<ref name="thenational1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/bouazizi-has-become-a-tunisian-protest-symbol|author=Thorne, John|title=Bouazizi has become a Tunisian protest 'symbol'|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|date=2011-01-13|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> and suffering an unemployment rate estimated at 30%.<ref name="nytimes1"/> According to his mother, he applied to join the army, but was refused, and several subsequent job applications also resulted in rejection.<ref name="aljazeera1"/> He supported his mother, uncle, and younger siblings, including paying for one of his sisters to attend university, by earning approximately {{Currency|140}} per month selling [[produce]] on the street in Sidi Bouzid.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref name="aljazeera1"/> He was also working toward the goal of buying or renting a pickup truck for his work.<ref name="time mag"/> A close friend of Bouazizi said he "was a very well-known and popular man [who] would give free fruit and vegetables to very poor families".<ref name="aljazeera1"/>
+
Bouazizi lived in a modest stucco home, a 20-minute walk from the center of Sidi Bouzid,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0119/In-town-at-center-of-Tunisia-uprising-23-years-of-repressed-emotions-burst-forth|author=Chick, Kristen|title=Tunisian emotions burst forth|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref><ref name="reuters1">{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE70G18J20110119 |title=Peddler's martyrdom launched Tunisia's revolution|author=Noueihed, Lin|publisher=Reuters|date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> a rural town in Tunisia burdened by corruption<ref name="thenational1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/bouazizi-has-become-a-tunisian-protest-symbol|author=Thorne, John|title=Bouazizi has become a Tunisian protest 'symbol'|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|date=2011-01-13|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> and suffering an unemployment rate estimated at 30%.<ref name="nytimes1"/> According to his mother, he applied to join the army, but was refused, and several subsequent job applications also resulted in rejection.<ref name="aljazeera1"/> He supported his mother, uncle, and younger siblings, including paying for one of his sisters to attend university, by earning approximately {{Currency|140}} per month selling [[produce]] on the street in Sidi Bouzid.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref name="aljazeera1"/> He was also working toward the goal of buying or renting a pickup truck for his work.<ref name="time mag"/> A close friend of Bouazizi said he "was a very well-known and popular man [who] would give free fruit and vegetables to very poor families".<ref name="aljazeera1"/>
==Confiscation of wares and self-immolation==
==Confiscation of wares and self-immolation==
â
According to friends and family, local police officers had allegedly targeted and mistreated Bouazizi for years, including during his childhood, regularly confiscating his small wheelbarrow of produce;<ref name="aljazeera1"/> but Bouazizi had few options to try to make a living, so he continued to work as a street vendor. Around {{nowrap|10 p.m.}} on December 16, 2010, he had contracted approximately {{Currency|200}} in debt to buy the produce he was to sell the following day. On the morning of December 17, he started his workday at 8 a.m.<ref name="guardian1"/> Just after {{nowrap|10:30 a.m.}}, the police began harassing him again, ostensibly because he did not have a vendor's permit.<ref name="time mag">{{Citation|author=Abouzeid, Rania|title=Postcard: Sidi Bouzid|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|pages=8|date=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, while some sources state that [[street vending]] is illegal in Tunisia,<ref name="guardian2">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/jan/19/tunisia-democratic-unity-government|author=Kherigi, Intissar|title=Tunisia needs real freedom|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-26|location=London}}</ref> and others that Bouazizi lacked a required permit to sell his wares,<ref name="guardian1"/><ref name="time mag"/> according to the head of Sidi Bouzid's state office for employment and independent work, no permit is needed to sell from a cart.<ref name="thenational1"/>
+
According to friends and family, local police officers had allegedly targeted and mistreated Bouazizi for years, including during his childhood, regularly confiscating his small wheelbarrow of produce;<ref name="aljazeera1"/> but Bouazizi had few options to try to make a living, so he continued to work as a street vendor. Around {{nowrap|10 p.m.}} on December 16, 2010, he had contracted approximately {{Currency|200}} in debt to buy the produce he was to sell the following day. On the morning of December 17, he started his workday at 8 a.m.<ref name="guardian1"/> Just after {{nowrap|10:30 a.m.}}, the police began harassing him again, ostensibly because he did not have a vendor's permit.<ref name="time mag">{{Citation|author=Abouzeid, Rania|title=Postcard: Sidi Bouzid|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|page=8|date=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, while some sources state that [[street vending]] is illegal in Tunisia,<ref name="guardian2">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/jan/19/tunisia-democratic-unity-government|author=Kherigi, Intissar|title=Tunisia needs real freedom|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-26|location=London}}</ref> and others that Bouazizi lacked a required permit to sell his wares,<ref name="guardian1"/><ref name="time mag"/> according to the head of Sidi Bouzid's state office for employment and independent work, no permit is needed to sell from a cart.<ref name="thenational1"/>
It has also been claimed that Bouazizi did not have the funds to [[bribe]] police officials to allow his street vending to continue.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0114/Sticking-a-fork-in-Tunisia-s-Ben-Ali|author=Murphy, Dan|title=Sticking a fork in Tunisia's Ben Ali |publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=2011-01-14|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> Similarly, two of Bouazizi's siblings accused authorities of attempting to [[extort]] money from their brother,<ref name="thenational1"/> and during an interview with [[Reuters]], one of his sisters stated, "What kind of repression do you imagine it takes for a young man to do this? A man who has to feed his family by buying goods on credit when they fine him ... and take his goods. In Sidi Bouzid, those with no connections and no money for bribes are humiliated and insulted and not allowed to live."<ref name="reuters1"/>
It has also been claimed that Bouazizi did not have the funds to [[bribe]] police officials to allow his street vending to continue.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0114/Sticking-a-fork-in-Tunisia-s-Ben-Ali|author=Murphy, Dan|title=Sticking a fork in Tunisia's Ben Ali |publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=2011-01-14|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> Similarly, two of Bouazizi's siblings accused authorities of attempting to [[extort]] money from their brother,<ref name="thenational1"/> and during an interview with [[Reuters]], one of his sisters stated, "What kind of repression do you imagine it takes for a young man to do this? A man who has to feed his family by buying goods on credit when they fine him ... and take his goods. In Sidi Bouzid, those with no connections and no money for bribes are humiliated and insulted and not allowed to live."<ref name="reuters1"/>
Line 32: Line 32:
Regardless, Bouazizi's family claims he was publicly humiliated when a 45-year-old female [[municipal]] official, Faida Hamdi,<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref name="independent1">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/tunisia-i-have-lost-my-son-but-i-am-proud-of-what-he-did-2190331.html|title=Tunisia: 'I have lost my son, but I am proud of what he did'|publisher= [[The Independent]]|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-23|location=London}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera1"/> slapped him in the face, spat at him, confiscated his electronic weighing [[scales]], and tossed aside his produce cart.<ref name="time mag"/> It was also stated that she made a slur against his deceased father.<ref name="reuters1"/><ref name="time mag"/> Bouazizi's family says her gender made his humiliation worse.<ref name="independent1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.habibtoumi.com/2010/12/31/man-at-the-centre-of-tunisia-unrest-recuperating-doctors-say|author=Toumi, Habib|title=Man at the centre of Tunisia unrest recuperating, doctors say|publisher=HabibToumi.com|date=2010-12-31|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> His mother also claimed Hamdi's aides beat and swore at her son. Countering these claims, in an interview with ''[[Asharq Al-Awsat]]'', a brother of Hamdi claimed neither his sister nor her aides slapped or otherwise mistreated Bouazizi. He said they only confiscated Bouazizi's wares. However, an eyewitness told ''Asharq Al-Awsat'' that he did not see Hamdi slap Bouazizi, but that her aides did beat him.<ref name="AAA"/>
Regardless, Bouazizi's family claims he was publicly humiliated when a 45-year-old female [[municipal]] official, Faida Hamdi,<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref name="independent1">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/tunisia-i-have-lost-my-son-but-i-am-proud-of-what-he-did-2190331.html|title=Tunisia: 'I have lost my son, but I am proud of what he did'|publisher= [[The Independent]]|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-23|location=London}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera1"/> slapped him in the face, spat at him, confiscated his electronic weighing [[scales]], and tossed aside his produce cart.<ref name="time mag"/> It was also stated that she made a slur against his deceased father.<ref name="reuters1"/><ref name="time mag"/> Bouazizi's family says her gender made his humiliation worse.<ref name="independent1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.habibtoumi.com/2010/12/31/man-at-the-centre-of-tunisia-unrest-recuperating-doctors-say|author=Toumi, Habib|title=Man at the centre of Tunisia unrest recuperating, doctors say|publisher=HabibToumi.com|date=2010-12-31|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> His mother also claimed Hamdi's aides beat and swore at her son. Countering these claims, in an interview with ''[[Asharq Al-Awsat]]'', a brother of Hamdi claimed neither his sister nor her aides slapped or otherwise mistreated Bouazizi. He said they only confiscated Bouazizi's wares. However, an eyewitness told ''Asharq Al-Awsat'' that he did not see Hamdi slap Bouazizi, but that her aides did beat him.<ref name="AAA"/>
â
Bouazizi, angered by the confrontation,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/tunisia-revolt-sparked-by-a-police-slap/story-e6frg6so-1225990556122|title=Tunisia revolt sparked by a police slap |work=[[The Australian]]|date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> ran to the governor's office to complain<ref name="time mag"/> and to ask for his scales back.<ref name="cbs"/> Following the governor's refusal to see or listen to him, even after Bouazizi was quoted as saying "'If you don't see me, I'll burn myself',"<ref name="time mag"/> he acquired a can of [[gasoline]] from a nearby gas station and returned to the governor's office. While standing in the middle of traffic, he shouted "how do you expect me to make a living?"<ref name="cbs">{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/20/60minutes/main20033404.shtml | title=How a slap sparked Tunisia's Revolution | publisher=[[CBS News]] | date=2011-02-20 | accessdate=2011-04-25 | author=Simon, Bob | pages=1}}</ref> He then doused and set himself alight with a match at {{nowrap|11:30 a.m.}} local time, less than an hour after the altercation.<ref name="time mag">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043557,00.html|author=Abouzeid, Rania|title=Bouazizi: The Man Who Set Himself and Tunisia on Fire|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]''|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref>
+
Bouazizi, angered by the confrontation,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/tunisia-revolt-sparked-by-a-police-slap/story-e6frg6so-1225990556122|title=Tunisia revolt sparked by a police slap |work=[[The Australian]]|date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> ran to the governor's office to complain<ref name="time mag"/> and to ask for his scales back.<ref name="cbs"/> Following the governor's refusal to see or listen to him, even after Bouazizi was quoted as saying "'If you don't see me, I'll burn myself',"<ref name="time mag"/> he acquired a can of [[gasoline]] from a nearby gas station and returned to the governor's office. While standing in the middle of traffic, he shouted "how do you expect me to make a living?"<ref name="cbs">{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/20/60minutes/main20033404.shtml | title=How a slap sparked Tunisia's Revolution | publisher=[[CBS News]] | date=2011-02-20 | accessdate=2011-04-25 | author=Simon, Bob | page=1}}</ref> He then doused and set himself alight with a match at {{nowrap|11:30 a.m.}} local time, less than an hour after the altercation.<ref name="time mag">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043557,00.html|author=Abouzeid, Rania|title=Bouazizi: The Man Who Set Himself and Tunisia on Fire|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]''|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref>
==Death and funeral==
==Death and funeral==
â
According to Bouazizi's sister, people immediately panicked when he caught fire, and one of them tried to douse the flames with water, which only worsened his condition.<ref name="habibtoumi">http://www.habibtoumi.com/2010/12/31/man-at-the-centre-of-tunisia-unrest-recuperating-doctors-say/</ref> Bouazizi barely survived, and suffered severe burns over 90% of his body before locals managed to douse the flames. He was taken by ambulance to a medical facility in [[Sidi Bouzid]]. When they were unable to treat Bouazizi's severe burns, he was taken to a larger hospital in [[Sfax]], more than {{convert|70|mi|km}} away.<ref name="guardian1"/> Later, as the government's interest in his case grew, he was transferred to a Burn and Trauma Centre in [[Ben Arous]], where he was placed in an [[intensive care unit]].<ref>http://arabsahistory.com/?p=4</ref> On December 31, 2010, doctors at the Ben Arous Burn and Trauma Centre reported that Bouazizi was in stable condition, and that he was showing positive prognostic factors.<ref name="habibtoumi"/> However, he remained in a [[coma]] throughout the remainder of his life.<ref>http://www.lifeconstructionzone.com/2011/03/revolutions-of-hope-in-middle-east.html</ref>
+
According to Bouazizi's sister, people immediately panicked when he caught fire, and one of them tried to douse the flames with water, which only worsened his condition.<ref name="habibtoumi">{{cite web|url=http://www.habibtoumi.com/2010/12/31/man-at-the-centre-of-tunisia-unrest-recuperating-doctors-say/ |title=Man at the centre of Tunisia unrest recuperating, doctors say |publisher=Habib Toumi |date=2010-12-31 |accessdate=2011-06-18}}</ref> Bouazizi barely survived, and suffered severe burns over 90% of his body before locals managed to douse the flames. He was taken by ambulance to a medical facility in [[Sidi Bouzid]]. When they were unable to treat Bouazizi's severe burns, he was taken to a larger hospital in [[Sfax]], more than {{convert|70|mi|km}} away.<ref name="guardian1"/> Later, as the government's interest in his case grew, he was transferred to a Burn and Trauma Centre in [[Ben Arous]], where he was placed in an [[intensive care unit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arabsahistory.com/?p=4 |title=The Arabs by Eugene Rogan |publisher=Arabsahistory.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-18}}</ref> On December 31, 2010, doctors at the Ben Arous Burn and Trauma Centre reported that Bouazizi was in stable condition, and that he was showing positive prognostic factors.<ref name="habibtoumi"/> However, he remained in a [[coma]] throughout the remainder of his life.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jodi Orgill Brown |url=http://www.lifeconstructionzone.com/2011/03/revolutions-of-hope-in-middle-east.html |title=Life Under Construction: Revolutions of Hope in the Middle East |publisher=Lifeconstructionzone.com |date=2011-03-28 |accessdate=2011-06-18}}</ref>
Bouazizi was visited in hospital by then-President [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tunisiaonlinenews.com/president-zine-el-abidine-ben-ali-visits-young-man-mohamed-bouazizi/|title=President Zine el Abidine Ben Ali visits young man Mohamed Bouazizi|publisher=Tunisia-tour.com|date=|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> According to Bouazizi's mother, Ben Ali promised to send him to [[France]] for medical treatment,<ref name="aljazeera1"/> but no such transfer was ever arranged. Bouazizi died at the Ben Arous Burn and Trauma Centre 18 days after the immolation, on January 4, 2011, at {{nowrap|5:30 p.m.}} local time.<ref>{{cite news|author=Whitaker, Brian|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2010/dec/28/tunisia-ben-ali|title=How a man setting fire to himself sparked an uprising in Tunisia|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2010-12-28|accessdate=2011-01-23|location=London}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera2">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201115101926215588.html|title=Tunisian protester dies of burns|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=2011-01-05|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref>
Bouazizi was visited in hospital by then-President [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tunisiaonlinenews.com/president-zine-el-abidine-ben-ali-visits-young-man-mohamed-bouazizi/|title=President Zine el Abidine Ben Ali visits young man Mohamed Bouazizi|publisher=Tunisia-tour.com|date=|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> According to Bouazizi's mother, Ben Ali promised to send him to [[France]] for medical treatment,<ref name="aljazeera1"/> but no such transfer was ever arranged. Bouazizi died at the Ben Arous Burn and Trauma Centre 18 days after the immolation, on January 4, 2011, at {{nowrap|5:30 p.m.}} local time.<ref>{{cite news|author=Whitaker, Brian|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2010/dec/28/tunisia-ben-ali|title=How a man setting fire to himself sparked an uprising in Tunisia|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2010-12-28|accessdate=2011-01-23|location=London}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera2">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201115101926215588.html|title=Tunisian protester dies of burns|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=2011-01-05|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref>
Line 57: Line 57:
{{main|Tunisian Revolution#Protests}}
{{main|Tunisian Revolution#Protests}}
[[Image:Caravane de la libÃ©ration 4.jpg|thumb|Tunisian street protests]]
[[Image:Caravane de la libÃ©ration 4.jpg|thumb|Tunisian street protests]]
â
Outraged by the events that led to Bouazizi's self-immolation, [[2010-2011 Tunisian protests|protests]] began in Sidi Bouzid within hours,<ref name="thenational1"/> building for more than two weeks, with attempts by police to quiet the unrest serving only to fuel what had become a violent and deadly movement.<ref name="aljazeera3"/> After Bouazizi's death, the protests became widespread, moving into the more affluent areas and eventually into the capital.<ref name="time mag"/> The anger and violence became so intense that President Ben Ali fled Tunisia with his family on January 14, 2011,<ref name="time mag"/> trying first to go to [[Paris]], but was refused refuge by the [[France|French government]]. They were eventually welcomed into [[Saudi Arabia]] under "a long list of conditions" (such as being barred from participation in the media and politics), ending his 23-year rule and sparking "angry condemnation" among Saudis.<ref name="aljazeera3">{{Cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201111652129710582.html|title=Ben Ali gets refuge in Saudi Arabia|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=2011-01-24}}</ref> In Tunisia, unrest persisted as a new regime took over, leaving many citizens of Tunisia feeling as though their needs were still being ignored.<ref name="TIME">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043557,00.html|author=Abouzid, Rania|title=Bouazizi: The Man Who Set Himself and Tunisia on Fire|work=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-24}}</ref>
+
Outraged by the events that led to Bouazizi's self-immolation, [[2010-2011 Tunisian protests|protests]] began in Sidi Bouzid within hours,<ref name="thenational1"/> building for more than two weeks, with attempts by police to quiet the unrest serving only to fuel what had become a violent and deadly movement.<ref name="aljazeera3"/> After Bouazizi's death, the protests became widespread, moving into the more affluent areas and eventually into the capital.<ref name="time mag"/> The anger and violence became so intense that President Ben Ali fled Tunisia with his family on January 14, 2011,<ref name="time mag"/> trying first to go to [[Paris]], but was refused refuge by the [[France|French government]]. They were eventually welcomed into [[Saudi Arabia]] under "a long list of conditions" (such as being barred from participation in the media and politics), ending his 23-year rule and sparking "angry condemnation" among Saudis.<ref name="aljazeera3">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201111652129710582.html|title=Ben Ali gets refuge in Saudi Arabia|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=2011-01-24}}</ref> In Tunisia, unrest persisted as a new regime took over, leaving many citizens of Tunisia feeling as though their needs were still being ignored.<ref name="TIME">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043557,00.html|author=Abouzid, Rania|title=Bouazizi: The Man Who Set Himself and Tunisia on Fire|work=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-24}}</ref>
===Copycat incidents===
===Copycat incidents===
Line 63: Line 63:
Bouazizi's self-immolation triggered [[Copycat suicide|the Werther effect]], in which a number of self-immolation protests emulating Bouazizi's have taken place in several other countries in the [[Greater Middle East]] and [[Europe]]. In [[Algeria]], during protests against rising food prices and spreading unemployment,<ref name="Chinadaily">{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2011-01-25/content_1642189.html |title=Algeria reports 2nd death of self-immolation |author=Xinhua |date=2011-01-25 |work=[[China Daily]] |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> there have been [[2011 Algerian self-immolations|many cases]]. The first reported case following Bouazizi's death is among those whose attempted suicide was successful. Mohsen Bouterfif, a 37-year-old father of two, set himself on fire when the mayor of [[Boukhadra]] refused to meet with him and others regarding employment and housing requests on January 13, 2011. According to a report in ''[[El-Watan]]'', the mayor challenged him, saying if he had courage he would immolate himself by fire as Bouazizi had done.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1210-le-maire-a-mohcin-bouterfif-l-si-tu-as-du-courage-fais-comme-bouazizi-immole-toi-par-le-feu-r.html |title=Le maire Ã  Mohcin Bouterfif : " Si tu as du courage, fais comme Bouazizi, immole-toi par le feu " |publisher=DNA-Algerie |language=French |author=Benslimane, Mehdi & Slim Badaoui |date=2011-01-24 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> He died on January 24. Maamir Lotfi, a 36-year-old unemployed father of six who was denied a meeting with the governor, burned himself in front of the [[El Oued]] town hall on January 17. He died on February 12.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110212105526/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-manifestationquatrieme-deces-par-immolation-en-algerie-a-la-veille-de-la-marche-du-12-fevrier.html |title=QuatriÃ¨me dÃ©cÃ¨s par immolation en AlgÃ©rie, Ã  la veille de la marche du 12 fÃ©vrier |language=French |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |date=2011-02-12 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> Abdelhafid Boudechicha, a 29-year-old day laborer who lived with his parents and five siblings, burned himself in [[Medjana]] on January 28 over employment and housing issues. He died the following day.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-jeune-decede-apres-s-etre-immole-par-le-feu-a-bordj-bou-arreridj-29-01-2011-109323_109.php |title=Un jeune dÃ©cÃ¨de aprÃ¨s sâÃªtre immolÃ© par le feu Ã  Bordj Bou ArrÃ©ridj |author=A.B. |work=El Watan |language=French |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref>
Bouazizi's self-immolation triggered [[Copycat suicide|the Werther effect]], in which a number of self-immolation protests emulating Bouazizi's have taken place in several other countries in the [[Greater Middle East]] and [[Europe]]. In [[Algeria]], during protests against rising food prices and spreading unemployment,<ref name="Chinadaily">{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2011-01-25/content_1642189.html |title=Algeria reports 2nd death of self-immolation |author=Xinhua |date=2011-01-25 |work=[[China Daily]] |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> there have been [[2011 Algerian self-immolations|many cases]]. The first reported case following Bouazizi's death is among those whose attempted suicide was successful. Mohsen Bouterfif, a 37-year-old father of two, set himself on fire when the mayor of [[Boukhadra]] refused to meet with him and others regarding employment and housing requests on January 13, 2011. According to a report in ''[[El-Watan]]'', the mayor challenged him, saying if he had courage he would immolate himself by fire as Bouazizi had done.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1210-le-maire-a-mohcin-bouterfif-l-si-tu-as-du-courage-fais-comme-bouazizi-immole-toi-par-le-feu-r.html |title=Le maire Ã  Mohcin Bouterfif : " Si tu as du courage, fais comme Bouazizi, immole-toi par le feu " |publisher=DNA-Algerie |language=French |author=Benslimane, Mehdi & Slim Badaoui |date=2011-01-24 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> He died on January 24. Maamir Lotfi, a 36-year-old unemployed father of six who was denied a meeting with the governor, burned himself in front of the [[El Oued]] town hall on January 17. He died on February 12.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110212105526/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-manifestationquatrieme-deces-par-immolation-en-algerie-a-la-veille-de-la-marche-du-12-fevrier.html |title=QuatriÃ¨me dÃ©cÃ¨s par immolation en AlgÃ©rie, Ã  la veille de la marche du 12 fÃ©vrier |language=French |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |date=2011-02-12 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> Abdelhafid Boudechicha, a 29-year-old day laborer who lived with his parents and five siblings, burned himself in [[Medjana]] on January 28 over employment and housing issues. He died the following day.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-jeune-decede-apres-s-etre-immole-par-le-feu-a-bordj-bou-arreridj-29-01-2011-109323_109.php |title=Un jeune dÃ©cÃ¨de aprÃ¨s sâÃªtre immolÃ© par le feu Ã  Bordj Bou ArrÃ©ridj |author=A.B. |work=El Watan |language=French |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref>
â
In [[Egypt]], Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar, a 49-year-old restaurant owner, set himself alight in front of the [[Egyptian Parliament]].<ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/2/4115/Egypt/Society/In-Egypt,-man-sets-himself-on-fire.aspx|title=In Egypt, man sets himself on fire, driven by economic woes|work=English [[Al-Ahram]] |date=2011-01-17|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> His act of protest contributed to the instigation of weeks of protest and, later, the resignation of Egyptian President [[Hosni Mubarak]] on February 11, 2011. In [[Saudi Arabia]], an unidentified 65-year-old man died on January 21, 2011, after setting himself on fire in the town of [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]]. This was apparently the kingdom's first known case of self-immolation.<ref name="saudi">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12260465 |title=Man dies after setting himself on fire in Saudi Arabia |date=2011-01-23 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=2011-01-23 }}</ref><ref name="saudi2">{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/world-news/4231-man-dies-in-possible-first-self-immolation-in-saudi |title=Man dies in possible first self-immolation in Saudi |author=Mifthah, Mohideen |date=2011-01-22 |work=[[The Sunday Times]] |accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref>
+
In [[Egypt]], Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar, a 49-year-old restaurant owner, set himself alight in front of the [[Egyptian Parliament]].<ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/2/4115/Egypt/Society/In-Egypt,-man-sets-himself-on-fire.aspx|title=In Egypt, man sets himself on fire, driven by economic woes|work=English [[Al-Ahram]] |date=2011-01-17|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> His act of protest contributed to the instigation of weeks of protest and, later, the resignation of Egyptian President [[Hosni Mubarak]] on February 11, 2011. In [[Saudi Arabia]], an unidentified 65-year-old man died on January 21, 2011, after setting himself on fire in the town of [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]]. This was apparently the kingdom's first known case of self-immolation.<ref name="saudi">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12260465 |title=Man dies after setting himself on fire in Saudi Arabia |date=2011-01-23 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2011-01-23 }}</ref><ref name="saudi2">{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/world-news/4231-man-dies-in-possible-first-self-immolation-in-saudi |title=Man dies in possible first self-immolation in Saudi |author=Mifthah, Mohideen |date=2011-01-22 |work=[[The Sunday Times]] |accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref>
Although these cases, with the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|exception of Egypt]], did not provoke the same kind of popular reaction that Bouazizi's case did in Tunisia, the Algerian, [[Yemen]]i, and [[Jordan]]ian governments have experienced significant protests and made major concessions in response to them.<ref name="time mag"/> As such, these men and Bouazizi are being hailed by some as "heroic martyrs of a new Middle Eastern revolution."<ref name="nytimes2">{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/23/weekinreview/23worth.html?src=twrhp |author=Worth, Robert F. |title=How a Single Match Can Ignite a Revolution |work=[[New York Times]] |date=2011-01-21 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
Although these cases, with the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|exception of Egypt]], did not provoke the same kind of popular reaction that Bouazizi's case did in Tunisia, the Algerian, [[Yemen]]i, and [[Jordan]]ian governments have experienced significant protests and made major concessions in response to them.<ref name="time mag"/> As such, these men and Bouazizi are being hailed by some as "heroic martyrs of a new Middle Eastern revolution."<ref name="nytimes2">{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/23/weekinreview/23worth.html?src=twrhp |author=Worth, Robert F. |title=How a Single Match Can Ignite a Revolution |work=[[New York Times]] |date=2011-01-21 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
â
The wave of copycat incidents reached Europe on February 11, 2011, in a case very similar to Bouazizi's. Noureddine Adnane, a 27-year-old [[Morocco|Moroccan]] street vendor, set himself on fire in [[Palermo]], [[Sicily]], in protest of the confiscation of his wares and the harassment that was allegedly inflicted on him by municipal officials.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.agi.it/english-version/italy/elenco-notizie/201102121012-cro-ren1017-street_vendor_sets_himself_on_fire_in_palermo_critical |title=Street Vendor Sets Himself on Fire in Palermo, Critical |publisher=[[Agenzia Giornalistica Italia]] |date=2011-02-12 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> He died five days later.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ahoraitalia.com/giornale//117595/palermo-dies-after-setting-himself-fire.htm |title=Palermo, Moroccan street vendor dies after setting himself on fire | publisher=Ahora Italia |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> In [[Amsterdam]], Kambiz Roustay, a 36-year-old asylum-seeker from Iran, set himself on fire on [[Dam Square]], in protest against being rejected asylum. He feared being tortured by the [[Iran]]ian regime on return as he fled the country for publications undermining the regime.<ref>http://www.at5.nl/artikelen/60029/iranier-waarschuwde-al-voor-wanhoopsdaad</ref>
+
The wave of copycat incidents reached Europe on February 11, 2011, in a case very similar to Bouazizi's. Noureddine Adnane, a 27-year-old [[Morocco|Moroccan]] street vendor, set himself on fire in [[Palermo]], [[Sicily]], in protest of the confiscation of his wares and the harassment that was allegedly inflicted on him by municipal officials.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.agi.it/english-version/italy/elenco-notizie/201102121012-cro-ren1017-street_vendor_sets_himself_on_fire_in_palermo_critical |title=Street Vendor Sets Himself on Fire in Palermo, Critical |publisher=[[Agenzia Giornalistica Italia]] |date=2011-02-12 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> He died five days later.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ahoraitalia.com/giornale//117595/palermo-dies-after-setting-himself-fire.htm |title=Palermo, Moroccan street vendor dies after setting himself on fire | publisher=Ahora Italia |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> In [[Amsterdam]], Kambiz Roustay, a 36-year-old asylum-seeker from Iran, set himself on fire on [[Dam Square]], in protest against being rejected asylum. He feared being tortured by the [[Iran]]ian regime on return as he fled the country for publications undermining the regime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.at5.nl/artikelen/60029/iranier-waarschuwde-al-voor-wanhoopsdaad |title=IraniÃ«r waarschuwde al voor wanhoopsdaad - AT5 Nieuws |publisher=At5.nl |date=2011-04-07 |accessdate=2011-06-18}}</ref>
